questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a history of headaches and balance difficulties over the past few months. Histopathological examination of the biopsy shows bipolar cells with long, thin hairlike processes, dense fibrillary meshwork, and characteristic eosinophilic corkscrew-shaped inclusions. Which inclusion bodies are involved in this type of tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rosenthal fibers

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings point towards diagnosing Pilocytic astrocytoma, low-grade brain tumors commonly found in children and young adults.

  • They are characterized by their slow growth and relatively benign behavior.
  • The histopathology shows bipolar cells with elongated processes and characteristic eosinophilic inclusions like Rosenthal fibers and mulberry bodies (eosinophilic granular bodies)
  • These tumors are often well-demarcated and cystic, with a contrast-enhancing mural nodule seen on imaging.

Glomeruloid bodies (Option B) :

  • Glomeruloid bodies are a characteristic feature of Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM).

Negri bodies (Option C) :

  • Negri bodies are eosinophilic, inclusion bodies typically found in neurons infected with the rabies virus

Lewy bodies (Option D):

  • Lewy bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions composed primarily of alpha-synuclein protein.
  • They are characteristic pathological features of Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding primary CNS lymphoma?

choices.text: Caused by underexpression of PDL1 gene

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Caused by EB Virus (EBV)

 

Explanation:

Primary CNS lymphoma

  • It is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus in immunosuppressed cases and PDL1 gene overexpression in others.
  • These diffuse large B-cell lymphomas present as multiple, aggressive, grey-white masses in deep brain regions, often spreading in the periventricular areas.

The cells are angiocentric and have areas of necrosis, expressing CD20.

Primary CNS lymphoma where the malignant B cells show angiocentric hooping patterns.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with right-sided hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo has an MRI showing a mass at the right cerebellopontine angle from the vestibulocochlear nerve. Biopsy reveals encapsulated tissue with areas of dense cellularity and loose myxoid regions, as depicted in the image below. Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical details and histopathological findings are consistent with a diagnosis of schwannoma.

  • It is associated with NF2 mutations (not NF1) on chromosome 22, producing merlin. (Option C)
  • They mostly occur in the cerebellopontine angle
  • Microscopically, they are comprised of
  • Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively.
    • Antoni A: Dense eosinophilic areas containing spindle cells are arranged into intersecting fascicles, leading to nuclei palisading.
      • The resulting structures with central “nuclear-free zones” are called Verocay bodies. (Option B)
    • Antoni B: Loose, hypocellular areas where a myxoid extracellular matrix spreads apart the spindle cells.
  • It typically shows immunoreactivity to S-100.(Option D)

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female presents with persistent headaches and weakness in her right upper limbs. Imaging reveals a brain tumor that is PR+. Biopsy reveals psammoma bodies with necrosis, cellular atypia, mitosis >4/hpf, and invasion of brain parenchyma. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atypical meningioma

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and biopsy features suggest Atypical meningiomas characterized by the presence of psammoma bodies with areas of necrosis, cellular atypia, mitosis >4/hpf, and invasion of brain parenchyma.

  • They arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid and are attached to the dura.
  • These PR+ tumors of adults are locally aggressive and are associated with higher recurrence rates.
  • They are distinguished from lower-grade meningiomas by having
    • Increased mitotic index (>4/hpf and <20/hpf)
    • Brain invasion
    • Cellular atypia
    • Areas of necrosis
    • Prominent nucleoli
    • High N: C ratio
    • Disorganised growth

 

Typical Meningioma (Option A):

  • A typical meningioma is characterized by slow growth, well-defined borders, and low mitotic activity.
  • It is a benign dural masses that compress the underlying brain but are easily separated from it.
  • They are PR+, non-aggressive, and do not invade the underlying brain parenchyma.

 

Anaplastic meningioma (Option C):

  • Anaplastic meningioma is a highly aggressive malignant tumor that often resembles a carcinoma or sarcoma.
  • It’s Mitotic index is >20/hpf.

 

Papillary meningioma (Option D):

  • Papillary meningioma is a variant of anaplastic meningioma and is also highly aggressive with a mitotic index of >20/hpf.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old gravid woman comes to the ODP due to a severe headache that started during her pregnancy. Investigations reveal the following. Which of the following statements is not true for the above condition?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Risk factors include exposure to radiation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HPE shows perivascular pseudo-rosettes

 

Explanation:

  • Perivascular pseudo-rosette is seen in Ependymomas.
  • The clinical presentation suggests Meningiomas, which are mostly benign tumors found in adults.
  • They originate from meningothelial cells of the arachnoid layer and are typically connected to the dura mater.
  • More common in women and has increased risk with pregnancy, exposure to radiation (Option B), and NF2 gene mutation (Option C).
  • Tumors typically exhibit a rubbery dural mass, compressing the brain, yet easily separable.
  • Histopathologically, they present with a whorled pattern of cells and psammoma bodies and are progesterone receptor-positive (Option A).

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of persistent morning headaches, vomiting, and difficulty with coordination for the past two months. MRI shows a mass in the cerebellum, and HPE shows Homer Wright's rosette. What is the most common route of metastasis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Drop metastasis

Explanation:

  • Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor that occurs mainly in children, exclusively in the cerebellum.
  • It is a WHO-grade IV tumor with poor prognosis.
  • Metastasis occurs via CSF-Drop metastasis from the cerebellum to the spinal cord.
  • Histology reveals small round blue cells with scanty cytosol and Homer Wright rosettes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a severe headache and blurring of vision. MRI indicates an intraventricular mass in the posterior fossa obstructing the CSF flow. Following surgical resection, which histopathological finding is most probable on examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Perivascular pseudorosette

Explanation:

  • Ependymomas are tumors that typically develop near the ependyma-lined ventricular system.
  • They frequently obstruct CSF flow, leading to obstructive hydrocephalus.
  • It most commonly arises from the floor of the 4th ventricle in children and in adults, spinal cord tumors are most common, especially in those with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).
  • Characteristic histopathological features of ependymomas include perivascular pseudorosettes, cells with fibrillary processes, and round to oval nuclei.

 

Perinuclear halo (Option B): Oligodendroglioma

Psammoma bodies (Option C): Meningioma

questions.text:
Identify the following CNS cells and match them with their specific roles:

 


	
		
			
			1.Fibrous astrocytes
			
			
			A.It is found primarily in white matter and maintains the blood-brain barrier
			
		
		
			
			2 .Oligodendrocyte
			
			
			B. Line the brain's ventricles and assist in producing cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
			
		
		
			
			3.Ependymal cell
			
			
			C. Produce myelin sheath for fast impulse conduction in the CNS.
			
		
		
			
			4.Protoplasmic astrocytes
			
			
			D. Phagocytize pathogens in CNS and are physiologically and embryologically unrelated to other neural cell types.
			
		
		
			
			5.Microglia
			
			
			E. They are found in the grey matter and help maintain the appropriate concentration of neurotransmitters.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1- A, 2-C, 3-B, 4-E, 5-D

 

Explanation:

 

Cells of the central nervous system

Glial cells:

Astrocytes

Oligodendrocytes

Ependymal cells
  • Star-shaped cells.
  • Immunohistochemistry stain: Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein (GFAP) marker.
  • Functions: Formation of the blood-brain barrier, structural support, and repair mechanism.
 

Types:

  • Fibrous astrocytes: Found in white matter and contain intermediate filaments. (A)
  • Protoplasmic astrocytes: Found in grey matter and have granular cytoplasm. Maintain appropriate concentration of ions and neurotransmitters. (E)
  • Form myelin on neighboring axons.
  • Helps in the fast conduction of impulses in the CNS. (C)
 

Associated diseases:

  • Guillain–Barré syndrome.
  • Multiple sclerosis.
  • Charcot-MarieTooth disease.
 

Myelin stain: Luxol fast blue.
  • Present in ventricles of the brain.
  • Production and circulation of CSF. (B)

 

Astrocytes and their cell processes around capillaries (brown).

Microglia:

  • Scavenger cells arise from macrophages outside the nervous system. (D)

questions.text: According to the Anne Mayo grading system, what grade would be assigned to the tumor showing hypercellularity, nuclear atypia, and mitotic activity but no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade 3

Explanation:

The St. Anne-Mayo grading system is a 4 tiered system and uses the presence of 4 morphologic criteria (AMEN) to assign a grade:

  • Nuclear Atypia
  • Mitosis
  • Endothelial proliferation - 'piled-up' endothelial cells. (NOT hypervascularity)
  • Necrosis

 

The grade then depends on the accumulation of these criteria as follows:

  • Grade 1: No AMEN
  • Grade 2: Only atypia
  • Grade 3: Atypia and mitosis
  • Grade 4: Atypia, mitosis, endothelial proliferation ± Necrosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with new-onset headaches, seizures, and progressive unilateral weakness. Brain MRI reveals a cerebral mass with irregular borders and heterogeneous contrast enhancement. Biopsy shows GFAP-positive glial cells. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Astrocytoma

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and biopsy showing GFAP (Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein) positivity indicates a Glial cell tumor, Astrocytoma, the most common primary brain tumor in children.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b,2-c,3-a,4-d

Explanation:

Neuronophagia:

  • Neuronophagia is a reaction of the microglial cells to injury.
  • There are congregating cell bodies of dying neurons.
  • It is seen in infections such as polio and rabies

 

 

Rabies:

  • Negri bodies, the pathognomonic microscopic finding, are cytoplasmic, inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum

 

 

Microglial nodules:

  • They are seen in HIV infection of the brain.

 

Krabbe’s disease:

  • Krabbe disease is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy resulting from a deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase.
  • The unique and diagnostic feature is the aggregation of engorged macrophages (globoid cells) in the brain parenchyma

questions.text: Which of the following features are not seen in Alzheimer’s Disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bunina bodies

Explanation:

  • Bunina bodies are seen in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). They are PAS-positive cytoplasmic inclusions, which appear to be remnants of autophagic vacuoles.
  • They contain two proteins, cystatin, and transferrin, and are considered a hallmark of ALS.

 

Histology of Alzheimer’s disease:

Plaques
  • Deposits of Aβ peptides in the neuropil.
  • Neuritic plaques contain both Aβ 40 and Aβ 42.

Tangles
  • Aggregates of the microtubule-binding protein tau.
  • Demonstrated by silver (Bielschowsky) staining.

Hirano bodies
  • Composed of Actin (intracellular inclusions)

Granulovacuolar degeneration
  • Formation of small, clear vacuoles within the neurons.


 

Plaques

Neurofibrillary tangles

Hirano bodies

Granulovacuolar degeneration

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Alzheimer’s Disease is/are correct?

 

1) Due to the mutation of the APP gene on Chromosome 21

2) Alpha and Gama secretase pathways are involved

3) APOE2 is a risk factor

4) Affects the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,4

Explanation:

  • Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurological disorder causing memory loss, cognitive decline, and personality changes.
  • Alzheimer's Disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly.
  • It affects the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes (Statement 4).
  • It occurs due to the mutation of the APP gene on Chromosome 21 (Statement 1).
    • If APP is processed by alpha and gamma-secretase pathways, products are soluble and do not deposit in the brain, and there is no disease. (Statement 2).
    • If the beta-secretase pathway processes APP, it produces amyloid products, which are pathogenic.
  • APOE2 is considered a protective factor for Alzheimer's Disease (Statement 3).
  • Genetics of Alzheimer's Disease:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of resting tremor in his right hand, which improves with movement. He reports increasing slowness in daily activities and stiffness, particularly in the morning. He has had occasional falls due to unsteadiness while walking. Physical examination reveals a shuffling gait and cogwheel rigidity. All of the following are true statements regarding this condition except?

choices.text: A key pathological feature in the substantia nigra neurons is observed.
This condition can occur due to mitochondrial dysfunction.
Mutations in LRRK2 are the most common cause of autosomal dominant disease.
Homozygous mutation of glucocerebrosidase is an important risk factor for this condition.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Homozygous mutation of glucocerebrosidase is an important risk factor for this condition

Explanation:

  • The clinical vignette of resting tremors, early morning stiffness, unsteadiness, shuffling gait, and cogwheel rigidity is suggestive of Parkinson’s disease.
  • Homozygous mutations in glucocerebrosidase cause Gaucher’s disease, a lysosomal storage disorder.

 

Parkinson’s Disease (PD):

Autosomal dominant PD is SNCA, a gene that encodes α-synuclein. This protein is a major component of the Lewy body, which is the diagnostic hallmark of PD.

Autosomal recessive forms of PD, are caused by gene mutations that encode the proteins DJ-1, PINK1, and parkin (Option B).

Mutations in the gene encoding LRRK2 (leucine-rich repeat kinase 2) are the most common cause of autosomal dominant PD (Option C).

 

  • Clinical Features: Triad of tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia.
  • Morphology:
    • A characteristic gross finding in PD is pallor of the substantia nigra
    • Lewy bodies are usually single or multiple, cytoplasmic, eosinophilic, round to elongated inclusions.
      • They have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo.

Ultrastructurally, they are composed of fine filaments (composed of α-synuclein)

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presented with behavioral changes and involuntary movements over the past several weeks. Neurological examination revealed ataxia and myoclonus. He passed away after 4 months, and biopsy findings of the brain tissue are shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?




	Proteinaceous particles with single-stranded RNA cause it.
	It results from the misfolding of PrPsc to PrPc.
	Spongiform transformation is a characteristic histopathological feature
	It is associated with a good prognosis if diagnosed early.
	Familial forms are associated with specific genetic mutations.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this clinical presentation is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a prion disease.

 

Prion Disease or Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathy (TSE):

  • Prions are proteinaceous infectious particles with no RNA/DNA.
  • Transmission: Iatrogenic, corneal transplant, cannibalism.
  • Genetics: Mutation of codon 129.
  • Pathogenesis: Misfolding of normal prion protein (PrPc) to form beta-pleated configuration (PrPSc).
  • Histopathology: Spongiform vacuolisation inside the cell.
  • Associated diseases:

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (M/C)
  • Genetic: Familial form caused by PRNP mutation.
  • Transmission: Iatrogenic
  • Symptoms:
    • Dementia.
    • Associated pronounced involuntary jerking muscle contractions on sudden stimulation (startle myoclonus) and cerebellar dysfunction (ataxia).
  • Histopathogenesis:
    • Spongiform transformation of the cerebral cortex.
  • Prognosis: Uniformly fatal with average survival < 7 months after the onset of symptoms.

Kuru disease
  • PAS & Congo: red positive.
  • Kuru plaques: Extracellular aggregated abnormal PrP.

Fatal familial insomnia

Bovine spongiform encephalopathy
